title-group.article-title: Self-reinforced nanocomposite by partial dissolution of cellulose microfibrils in ionic liquid

abstract.p: All-cellulose nanocomposite films with different ratios of cellulose I and II were produced by partial dissolution of microfibrillated cellulose using ionic liquid and subsequent film casting. The films were isotropic, transparent to visible light, highly crystalline, and contained different amounts of undissolved cellulose I crystallites in a matrix of dissolved cellulose. X-ray diffraction confirmed that cellulose I, i.e., the major polymorphic modification of cellulose in these nanocomposites, is rearranged to cellulose II crystal packing after the partial dissolution. The all-cellulose nanocomposite showed enhanced thermal properties, with thermal degradation temperature increased by 22% compared with thedissolved cellulose. The SEM and AFM studies verified that the nano-sized cellulose crystallites were well dispersed in the matrix. Results from DMA showed that the storage modulus was increased from 270 MPa for the dissolved cellulose to 1104 MPa for the nanocomposite with lower dissolution grade. This indicates that the all-cellulose nanocomposite films contained undissolved cellulose fragments – possibly cellulose I crystallites or aggregates of crystallites in a matrix of regenerated cellulose.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cellulose is a representative natural polysaccharide and is the most abundant organic substance on earth. For over a century, many researchers have been attracted by this natural substance as a central topic in macromolecular science.1–3 Many basic and practical studies concerning its structure, chemical and physical properties, biosynthesis, and morphology have been performed.1–4 The major limitation in extending novel application of cellulose is its strong inter- and intra-molecular hydrogen bonding, which resists the dissolution of the macromolecule by many solvents.4 It is hard to dissolve cellulose in water and most common organic solvents, unless superheated water is used, causing difficulty to obtain the composites containing cellulose as one component. To date, only a limited number of solvent systems for cellulose have been found, for example, the LiCl/N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) system.5

Investigations on the use of ionic liquids (ILs) as an alternative solvent have been steadily increased over the past 10 years.6,7 Their advantages are low melting points, wide liquid ranges, and lack of vapor pressure, which have encouraged researchers to explore known chemical reactions and processes using ILs instead of volatile organic solvents.6,7The interest in this study isthe utilization of the above-mentioned unique properties of ILs solvent for process applications of biopolymers.

The commercially available polymers used as composite matrices are currently petroleum based, non-biodegradable, and regarded as non-sustainable materials. In general, composites are composed of two chemically different materials. The interface between the incorporated fiber and the matrix often causes problems such as poor compatibility, insufficient stress transfer, and high water uptake. If the fiber and the matrix are both made of the same material, benefits such as recycle ability and good adhesion through the perfect interface can be expected. Similar to natural plant fibers, the use of regenerated cellulose fibers for the reinforcement of ‘green’ composites is increasing in importance. Following the successes of all-polymer composites like all-PP,8,9all-cellulose composites has recently been introduced.10–15 The term all-cellulose composite was first introduced by Nishino et al.10 for a material consisting of ramie fibers embedded in a matrix of regenerated cellulose. Monocomponent, all-cellulose composite materials have been developed in which the matrix is dissolved and then precipitated cellulose, while the reinforcement is undissolved or partly dissolved cellulose.10–15 Most studies related to all-cellulose composites have described the use of the LiCl/DMAc solvent system for dissolution of the cellulose.10–15

In this study, the aim has been to explore the use of IL, particularly 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([BMIM]+Cl−), as a novel solvent for nonderivatizing cellulose dissolution and regeneration.5 For this purpose, microfibrillated cellulose (MFC) was partly dissolved in IL solvent and films were casted from the solution. The concentration effect of the MFC in the solvent during preparation, which determines the amount of the outer layer of the MFC dissolved to form a matrix phase, was investigated. With decreased concentration and increased immersion time, larger fractions of the MFC can be dissolved to form a matrix phase and by that leading to composites with different compositions of the crystalline reinforcing phase. Since both the MFC and matrix phases of this cellulose nanocomposite are of the same origin and hence are chemically identical, a strong interfacial adhesion can be expected between them.10–14 The structure and microstructure of the prepared nanocomposites were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA), and by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: MFC (10.3% solid content, pH, 6.6, Ash, 0.3%) commercial product was supplied from Daicel Chemical Ind. LTD, Japan. The MFC was vacuum dried at 80°C for 2days before use. IL, [BMIM]+Cl− with a purity of >95% was obtained from BASF (category #38899) and used without further purification.

sec.title: Nanocomposite production
sec.p:
A mixture of MFC (3 and 5 g) with 100 g of IL ([BMIM]+Cl−), were heated at 100°C for 5 min with magnetic stirring to obtain a transparent solution. The solutions were then poured into Petri dishes (diameters 10 cm) with a thickness of 0.3–0.5 mm, the samples placed for 1 h on the laboratory bench in order to be cooled to room temperature and exposed to ambient moisture. This step increased the solvent viscosity and also stopped the dissolution process.16,17 Samples were then sequentially coagulated in water to obtain a transparent gel followed by washing with deionized water until no chloride ion was detected using AgNO3. The all-cellulose composites were dried at room temperature for 12 h and further under vacuum at 60°C for 24 h to ensure complete solidification. The final films were optically transparent and had a thickness between 0.4 and 0.6 mm and named as MD- and LD-cellulose. In order to evaluate the reinforcing effect of MFC, dissolved cellulose films were produced by dissolving 1 g of MFC for 4 h in 100 mL of [BMIM]+Cl− under constant stirring at 100°C. The solution was poured into a Petri dish and left as described above. The final films were optically transparent and had a thickness of 0.3 mm and named as HD-cellulose. sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: XRD was performed on the MFC, dissolved cellulose, and all-cellulose nanocomposites. X-ray patterns were obtained with a Philips PW1729 diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (k = 0.15418 nm), voltage of 50 kV, and a current of 40 mA with 2θ increased in steps of 0.02°. The X-ray data were smoothened over 100 adjacent points using the adjacent averaging smoothing function in Origin Pro 7.5 and plots were then area-normalized. The mechanically fractured surfaces of HD-cellulose and MD- and LD-nanocomposite films were studied in JEOL, JSM-5200 SEM. The films were fractured under liquid nitrogen and sputter coated with gold and using an acceleration voltage of 15 kV.

The morphology of prepared all-cellulose nanocomposites were studied using an AFM (Veeco Nanoscope V, Santa Barbara, USA) with a multi-mode head. The analysis was performed in tapping mode in air under moderate conditions, recording height and phase images.

The dynamic mechanical thermal properties were studied using DMA Q800, TA Instruments, (New Jersey, USA) in tensile mode. The temperature range was between 30–180°C in air atmosphere. The rectangular samples were tested in tensile mode with a heating rate of 3°C/min using a frequency of 1 Hz. The samples were measured by cutting strips from the films with a length of 12 mm, width 5.6 mm and thickness 0.3–0.5 mm. sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The films obtained in this study by partially dissolving MFC in [BMIM]+Cl− are referred to as all-cellulose nanocomposites because dissolved part of cellulose is supposed to serve as matrix, which is reinforced by cellulose I crystallites originating from undissolved cellulose. The film has two components that exhibit different structures and mechanical properties.21

X-ray diffractograms collected from MFC, HD-cellulose, MD- and LD-nanocomposites showed different crystalline structures (Figure 1 and Table 2). Partial dissolution was accompanied by a displacement of the (2 0 0) diffraction peak to lower values and an overall loss of crystallinity, as reported in studies of similar composites10 and13. In general, transformation was extensive for the HD-cellulose. CrI decreased with increasing dissolution, which was primarily controlled by concentration and dissolution time (Figure 1 and Table 2). All samples showed CrIs lower than that for the MFC (CrI = 0.79) (Table 2). This indicates partial dissolution for all the composites produced in this study, regardless of the dissolution time or concentration. In the XRD profile of the HD-cellulose (Figure 1(a)), the diffraction peaks due to crystallinestructures of the standard cellulose (Figure 1(d)) were not obviously exhibited. These XRD results indicate that the crystalline structures of the cellulose are largely disrupted in the dissolution (Table 2). The intensity distribution ofdissolved cellulose sheets formed after dissolving 1 g of MFC in 100 g of [BMIM]+Cl− indicates that the crystalline part of this film is cellulose II,22 with highest scattering intensity at 20.5° (Figure 1(a)). By contrast, the crystalline part of MFC corresponds to cellulose I17 and shows highest scattering intensity at 2θ = 22.8°.21 In contrast, the X-ray pattern of all-cellulose nanocomposites demonstrates two overlapping diffractions at 19.8° and 20.5°, which suggest that the regeneration part (cellulose II) appeared and laid over the native cellulosic fibers (cellulose I). In addition, a widening of diffraction line appeared at around 2θ = 20°, indicating that the regeneration part (cellulose II) turned into non-crystalline regions in the composite with the dissolving of the cellulose fibers gradually.23 The broadening of the peakcorresponds to the creation of the poorly crystalline phase that forms the matrix material, and it increases withdecreasing MFC content and increasing dissolution time.14,15 Figure 1.
X-ray diffractograms of nanofiber cellulose, regenerated cellulose, and all-cellulose nanocomposite films containing cellulose I and cellulose II: (a) dissolved MFC, (b) all-cellulose nanocomposites 3 wt%, (c) 5 wt%, and (d) pure MFC.

A comparison of Crl obtained from both nanocomposites made by partly dissolving different amounts of MFC in [BMIM]+Cl− reveals differences in crystallinity and cellulose I/cellulose II content. The lateral dimensions of cellulose crystallites in the nanocomposite films were evaluated by means of the Scherrer’s formula (Equation (2)) and typically are in the range 16–20 nm. Thus, we refer to the all-cellulose films produced here as nanocomposites of regenerated cellulose reinforced by cellulose I crystallites. This statement is supported by the fact that the all-cellulose nanocomposite films B and C show transparency (Figure 4). Since only components less than 1/10 of a wavelength in size provide optical transparency,24 it is expected that only nanoscale components are present in our all-cellulose composite films.

The reference sample and both nanocomposites (MD and LD) were viewed with SEM and the results are shown in Figure 2. It is possible to see that the fractured surfaces of the medium- and low-dissolution grade of MFC and all-cellulose nanocomposites were less smooth than the dissolved sample. The medium dissolved nanocomposite appeared to be smoother than the low dissolved nanocomposite. This gave us the indication that the MFC was uniformly dispersed in the cellulose matrix. Figure 2.
Scanning electron micrographs of cross-sectional view of: (a) dissolved cellulose, (b) all-nanocellulose 3 wt%, and(c) 5 wt% MFC concentrations in solution.

The AFM study showed very promising results. Cellulose nanocrystals were homogeneously dispersed in cellulose matrix and the smallest size of the nanocellulose was less than 100 nm. Further, the non-crystalline phase became increasingly prevalent as the cellulose concentration was decreased, regardless of the precipitation conditions. This is illustrated in Figure 3, where the low dissolved nanocomposites are shown. The relatively uniform gray area, occupying most of, surface was assigned to be the non-crystalline phase. This phase creates a matrix that surrounds the remaining undissolved cellulose crystals, seen as scattered white point with a diameter between 20 and 100 nm. This observation suggests that the surface of the MFC could be dissolved selectively, providing a matrix to cement adjacent fibers and lead to self-reinforced composite as proposed by Nishino and Arimoto.13 Figure 3.
Atomic force micrographs showing well-dispersed nanocrystallites in a cellulose matrix: (a) an overview and (b) a more detailed view. Figure 4.
Optical transparency observation of: (a) dissolved MFC, (b) all-cellulose nanocomposites with 3 wt% MFC (ACN3), and (c)all-cellulose nanocomposite with 5 wt% MFC (ACN5).

Figure 4 shows transparency of the dissolved and both MD- and LD-cellulose nanocomposites. The HD-cellulose shows a better optical transparency which is another indication for improved interfacial interaction as less light is scattered at their interfaces. The observation of optical transparency is another indication for an improved interfacial adhesion of the composites. This transparency requires a perfect interphase with a perfect bonding between matrix and fiber. Thus, the enhanced interface and the additional effect of the closure of the internal cell wall porosity by compression are thought to bring optical transparency tothis composite. The all-cellulose nanocomposite possesses a good interface between the remaining undissolved MFC and the surrounding matrix from the selectively dissolved/resolidified cellulose, resulting in an excellent bonding, a high mechanical performance, and an optical transparency.

The TGA results of the thermal stability of HD and the MD and LD all-cellulose nanocomposites are graphically represented in Figure 5. It can be clearly seen that there is a shift in the onset of weight loss of MD- and LD-nanocomposite if compared to HD reference material, indicating the undissolved part will actually enhance the properties of HD-cellulose making it more thermally stable. The HD-cellulose actually had onset of weight loss (Td) at around 197°C, while MD all-cellulose nanocomposite was at 224°C and LD at 240°C, respectively. The difference in the thermal degradation temperatures also indicates disruption of most of the crystalline regions of MFC in the dissolved cellulose. The results also indicate that MD nanocomposite was less thermally stable compared with LD-nanocomposites. This can be attributed to the higher crystalline content. Figure 5.
Thermal stability of: (a) dissolved cellulose and (b) all-cellulose nanocomposites ACN3 and (c) ACN5.

The storage modulus (E′) of the HD-cellulose and the MD- and LD-nanocomposites is shown as a function of temperature (Figure 6). The storage modulus of the nanocomposites was increased with increasing MFC concentration compared to the reference sample. This improvement might be due to the small size and large specific surface area of the nanocrystals which enables it to affect the polymer chain mobility of the matrix. There is a continuing decrease in modulus as a function of temperature. This decrease is relatively significant for the HD-cellulose and the MD-nanocomposite compared to the nanocomposite with lower dissolving degree (LD). The storage modulus values of the HD-cellulose and the MD- and LD-nanocomposites at 40°C are given in Table 2. Figure 6.
Storage modulus of: (a) dissolved reference cellulose and (b) all-cellulose nanocomposites ACN3 and (c) ANC5.

Figure 7 shows the tan δ curves of the HD-cellulose and the MD- and LD-nanocomposites as a function of temperature. The tan δ peaks recorded for the nanocomposites were shifted to higher temperatures compared to the tan δ peak for HD-cellulose. The temperature shift is quite remarkable, about 50–90°C, and indicates the undissolved part were able to affect the segmental motions of the dissolved cellulose. The height of tan δ of the nanocomposite with LD seems to decrease probably showing the decrease of the molecular mobility at the glass transition. An increase of the E′ and a shift of the tan δ peak to higher temperatures could be an indication of well-dispersed crystallites with good matrix interaction. With strong interaction between the reinforcing phase and the matrix, the polymer motion of the matrix is restricted.25 It can be seen that the nanocomposite has a boarder tan δ peak than for the HD-cellulose (Figure 7). This also indicates that the well-dispersed nanoparticles in the cellulose matrix.26 Figure 7.
Tan δ of: (a) dissolved reference cellulose and (b) all-cellulose nanocomposites ACN3 and (c) ACN5.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: All-cellulose nanocomposite films consisting of dissolved cellulose reinforced with undissolved cellulose Icrystallites were produced using partial dissolution of MFC cellulose in [BMIM]+Cl− and subsequent film casting. The random-oriented nanocrystallite-reinforced films were transparent and of high strength and stiffness with regard to comparable cellulosic materials. This composite possessed a good interface between the remaining fibers and the surrounding matrix from the selectively dissolved/resolidified MFC-fibril surfaces, which resulted in excellent bonding, good mechanical and thermal performances, and optical transparency. However, the major advantage of the new nanocomposite films is the fact that they are at the same time fullybiobased, easily recyclable, and biodegradable, yet reasonably strong materials.
